title: Are the Kennedys the most powerful family in American political history? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: No. The Kennedy Family has a strong influence on American politics from 1960 until some time in the mid 1990s. But that influence has dissipated, even with the young Joe Kennedy giving the State of the Union response recently. There is the question of how do you define “most powerful”? Most presidents? Four families have sired more than one president. Father/son John Adams and John Quincy Adams served as presidents, each for a single term. But the influence of the Adams Family ended when John Quincy Adams dropped dead on the House floor in 1848, where he served honorably after the conclusion of an undistinguished term as president. The Harrisons produced the grandfather/grandson combination of William Henry Harrison and Benjamin Harrison. William was fatally punished for delivering the longest inaugural address in U.S. history and served a mere 30 days. Benjamin served a single, very undistinguished term, virtually invisible to history. And the influence of that family ended with the second, non-consecutive inauguration of Grover Cleveland. Then there are the Roosevelts. Franklin and Theodore Roosevelt were distant relatives, but Theodore was the uncle of Franklin’s wife Eleanor, who also was a Roosevelt even before she married a Roosevelt. With that threesome, the family did have a strong influence on this country for a half-century. But I think the winner of “most powerful family” would the one who sired three presidents. This would be the Pierce/Bush family. Barbara Bush was Barbara Pierce before her marriage to George Herbert Walker Bush. So viewing this as one family, the Bush/Pierce Family produced Franklin Pierce, George H.W. Bush, and George W. Bush, the only president who was a direct lineal descendant of two presidents. Another son of George and Barbara, Jeb!, was a respected two-term governor of Florida (which is hard to remember after his unmitigated disaster of a presidential campaign). George H.W. Bush’s father was a senator in Connecticut. Thus, the Bushes are the only family on this list whose influence extended to at least three states: Texas, Florida and Connecticut. The influence has lasted to a fourth generation with young George P. Bush pursuing a political career — so far successfully — in Texas. So, right now, I would put the Bush/Pierce family in the lead for the title of “most powerful family” in U.S. political history.

Not sure where you would get that. The Kennedys have basically been irrelevant in American politics on a national level since Chappaquiddick ensured that Teddy would never become President. Their significance today is because they’re wealthy and they’re the subject of a lot of Baby Boomer nostalgia. JFK Jr. might have created a resurgence in their political influence had he lived longer, but I’m not sure he even wanted to. If any man had reason to be wary of U.S. politics, it was him. The Kennedys are still on the periphery of a lot of American politics, but Arnold Schwarzenegger and Andrew Cuomo didn’t become governors because they were once married to members of the Kennedy family. American political dynasties tend not to last more than a few generations. The Adamses, the Harrisons, Tafts, Stevensons, Kennedys, Bushes and Clintons have all had their moment in the sun at some level or another, but when it’s over, it’s over. Who’d have ever thought that Donald Trump, of all people, would be the end of the Bushes and the Clintons in the same political cycle?

No, I'd say it's a very close toss-up between the Roosevelts and the Bushes, who each produced two presidents. Both Roosevelts were great, but considering their families as a whole, I give the edge to the Bushes because they also produced a governor (Jeb), and George H. W. Bush's father, Prescott Bush, was a longtime U.S. senator from Connecticut. And now Jeb's son, George P. Bush, has moved from Florida to Texas and is expected to run for governor someday. From there--well, who knows. Evidently the family believes there's no such thing as too many presidents named George Bush.
No. That would be the Roosevelts. Both TR and FDR are rated in the top tier of Presidents and then add Eleanor to the mix!

Actually the most powerful family was probably the Rockefellers. They owned most of the old standard oil trust plus Chase-Manhattan bank. Next to them were the Duponts and the Mellons. I don’t think any other families came close to those three in terms of wealth and power.

Right now, Bush is the most powerful political family in the US. But that doesn’t mean they’re the most powerful family. DuPont, Bundy, Russell, Astor, Rockefeller, Rothschild and a few others are more powerful. Bush is the political wing of the really powerful families.
I would guess that the Clintons are the most powerful AND FEARED family in American political history considering the unlucky fate of anyone who planned on testifying against them.

I consider at least three other families in contention, two of them who haven’t much (if any) direct, public involvement in politics but, through their behind the scenes efforts, have shaped politics in the US: The Rockefellers, The Waltons, and the Kochs.
Hard to say, a strong argument COULD be made. Though evidence and not a small amount of dick measuring would need to take place against other families of political repute.
I would say 'no'. They might have the numbers but for 'power' the folks that founded the country are still the head of the class - they wrote the Constitution, you can't beat that for power.
The Roosevelts were equally powerful as a family.
